text: We'll hear argument next in No. 87-1490, John Mallard versus the United States District Court.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Yes, your Honor, that is correct.
And, in any event, the District Court found you were competent?
So, don't we take it as though you are in fact competent to do this work?
As an objective matter, the District Court has so found.
Does the court have authority to appoint someone to represent this indigent litigant?
Your honor, the way I read 1915(d) the answer is... is yes, that the court has authority to request an attorney to become involved in the case.
Well, what if everyone in the district says no?
--Your honor, I believe that that is actually... probably the only point that I am aware of that is a possible grounds of merit on the Respondent's side.
Well, yeah, I think in my day it would have been unthinkable to tell the judge you wouldn't do it.
Well, your Honor, I believe it's not quite that new, although I think my circumstances are more unusual in that I had a lot of discomfort with undertaking those responsibilities.
Well, you really haven't answered Justice O'Connor's question completely.
Your Honor, I regret if there is any ambiguity in my response, but I think it's based upon the usage of the word appoint.
But how about the authority to appoint someone like you who declined the request?
--Your Honor, I do not believe that that authority exists or was granted by Congress under 1915(d).
And this is a civil action, right?
What if it were a criminal action?
If it were a criminal action, I believe the court does possess the authority.
On the criminal side does it rest on the inherent power of the court?
--may I just be sure I understood something you said earlier.
--to the extent there would be a constitutional right involved possibly--
Well, I raise my constitutional objections only for the purpose that to the extent this Court found the plain meaning of 1915(d) to be unclear or ambiguous and upon looking--
You're merely arguing we should avoid the constitutional question by construing the statute in your favor?
--and you really don't think you have a constitutional claim on its own bottom?
I think that there would be serious constitutional claims if the statute were construed in the manner that the Respondent suggests, that the word "request" should mean require.
Mr. Mallard, may I interrupt you?
Do you think you were competent to represent yourself in this case?
You had exactly the same experience for this assignment as you had for the one down there that you declined.
--Your honor, I believe the skills are substantially different.
You don't have... don't need any skills up here, but you need a lot of skills down there?
--witnesses and be able to elicit testimony before a Jury.
Who was appointed under the English statute?

Your Honor, I cannot recall the distinction made, but some of the legal scholars who have worked in the area have suggested that the two types of lawyers, that the one was like a court employee or closer to the court, and that it was that class of attorneys who had to accept a court request.
The point is, if it was barristers, there would be no problem about a lawyer feeling himself... inexpert in the conduct of trials.
You just don't like the statute, do you?
--with the statute that it gives you your freedom.
And your freedom is to tell the court no.
Yes, that's the way I read 1915(d).
